results.title: The Thinking machine
results.creator_credit: Jon Palfreman, WGBH Productions and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The dream machine”.
Pioneers of “Artificial Intelligence” have reasoned that computers, like brains, are capable of manipulating ideas. However, efforts to simulate human thought in machines has been hindered by complexities such as ambiguous language and the process of acquiring knowledge and common sense. This program traces the complexities that have been encountered since 1958 when Marvin Minsky and John McArthy set up a department at M.I.T dealing with Artificial Intelligence.

results.title: The Paperback computer
results.creator_credit: Robert Hone, Jon Palfreman, WGBH Productions and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The dream machine”.
Explores the technological developments and the innovative research that paved the way for the Personal Computer Revolution of the 80’s. Focuses on the role hobbyists such as Steve Jobs and Stephen Wozniak (Co-founders of Apple Computer Company) played in making computers accessible with the introduction of the Macintosh in 1984. Examines the failure of companies such as Xerox and IBM to recognise potential markets outside the business and science arena and their failure to commercialise research discoveries in the 60’s and 70’s. Looks at the impact of PC’s and their extensive applications in today’s society and considers the endless possibilities for the future.

results.title: Inventing the future
results.creator_credit: Nancy Linde, WGBH Productions and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The dream machine”.
Looks at the development of commercial computer companies and the technologies and innovations that emerged in the 1950’s and 60’s. The designers and engineers Eckert and Mauchly set up the first computer company in 1946 but failed as businessmen. In England, the computer industry was co-operatively led by Cambridge University and Lyons (a company famous for tea and cakes). IBM entered the arena in 1951 when they recognised the need to compete with computers. FORTRAN and COBOL languages were developed to overcome the time-consuming problem of programming computers. Technological developments fuelled by the requirements of NASA’S space program and the Pentagon’s involvement in the Cold War witnessed the production of electronic components that were quicker, smaller, cheaper, more efficient and reliable.

results.title: Giant brains
results.creator_credit: Fiona Holmes, WGBH Productions and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The dream machine”.
This program traces the early development of the computer and introduces the pioneers who foresaw the universal application of these versatile machines capable of more than accurate calculations. Included is the work of Charles Babbage who invented the first computer in the 1800’s which mechanically compiled tables; Konrad Zuse’s use of electronic relays in the early 1930’s to represent information using the binary numbering system; John Mauchly and J. Presper Eckert who launched the ENIAC (Electronic Numeric Integrator and Computer) in the US in 1946 which used valves to carry out calculations; Freddie Williams who designed the first ‘Stored Programmed Computer’ using the Cathode Ray Tube to hold electronic information in 1949; the visionary work of Alan Turing who realised that computers could perform any logical task, on the basis of manipulating symbols according to rules, capable of simulating human thought.

results.title: The New morality
results.creator_credit: Mel Stuart, Richard Schickel and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Life goes to the movies”.
Hosted by Henry Fonda, Shirley MacLaine and Liza Minnelli. Takes a look at the life and career of Marilyn Monroe as well as the movies of the sixties. Their language, sexuality and violence portraying a new morality unthinkable a deecade earlier. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Fifties
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Life goes to the movies”.
Examines the impact of television and the courts’ decisions to separate film exhibition from production and distribution in Hollywood’s film industry during the period up to the seventies. Shows a series of film clips exemplifying the 1950’s preoccupation with romantic love themes. Suitable for Upper Secondary School Students.

results.title: The Post-war era
results.creator_credit: Mel Stuart, Richard Schickel, Malcolm Leo, Jack Haley and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Life goes to the movies”.
Hollywood turned to more mature themes in the late 1940s and early 1950s. Looks at “Film Noir” such as “Snake Pit” and “Lost Weekend”. Following McCarthyism hundreds of professionals were blacklisted. Another change of approach brought on a spate of monster films. Hosted by Henry Fonda. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The War years
results.creator_credit: Mel Stuart, Richard Schickel and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Life goes to the movies”.
Discusses Hollywood’s studio magnates and some of the 1939 spectacular films. Shows the industry’s was effort contribution via propaganda films, the creation of symbolic heroes and stars’ entertainment of the troops. Hosted by Henry Fonda and Shirley MacLaine.
